title: Obama's 'improbable journey' shaped by Nelson Mandela
content:
Obama said Mandela 'makes me want to be a better man . ' | REUTERS Obama : Mandela 'woke me up '
JOHANNESBURG — Toward the end of President Barack Obama ’ s roughly 15-minute speech at Nelson Mandela ’ s memorial service Tuesday , as the rainy skies over the stadium venue briefly brightened , his sights turned inward .
“ Over 30 years ago , while still a student , I learned of Nelson Mandela and the struggles in this beautiful land . It stirred something in me , ” he said slowly . “ And while I will always fall short of Madiba ’ s example , he makes me want to be a better man . ”
And at a dignitary-packed event equal parts sadness and celebration , the emotional , rain-soaked crowd — which saved some of its loudest cheers of the day for Obama ’ s arrival — responded with waves and cheers to his account of Mandela ’ s influence on his path to the presidency .
For the first U.S. president of African descent , paying tribute to South Africa ’ s first black president has a special kind of irresistible symmetry . But for Obama , the ties to Mandela and the anti-apartheid movement he led go much deeper than symbolism .
Obama cites the fight for equal rights in South Africa as the catalyst of his own political awakening as an American college student decades ago — the one that , as he said Tuesday , “ woke me up to my responsibilities — to others , and to myself — and set me on an improbable journey that finds me here today . ”
The line , for Obama , was no mere rhetorical flourish . Mandela ’ s legend , the battle against apartheid , and the continent of Africa are closely intertwined in fundamental ways with his own political ascendance , beginning with the youthful political awakening he described — and continuing to shape his decisions decades later .
The rock-star welcome he received on his 2006 trip there and the glowing press coverage it generated worldwide may also have helped convince Obama that his status as a cultural icon could play a key role in delivering him to the Oval Office .
“ That was what in a lot of ways propelled him onto TV sets and into the media . There were a lot of places in the world that didn ’ t even know a black U.S. senator had been elected , ” recalled Obama biographer David Mendell , who accompanied the then-senator as a reporter for the Chicago Tribune . “ Robert Gibbs predicted it would be a crazy trip , but he didn ’ t have idea quite the extent of the international coverage he would get….It was very important to [ Obama ’ s ] political jump . It was where Gibbs , [ adviser David ] Axelrod , and even Obama said : What ’ s going on here ? This is bigger than we ever thought . ”
Despite the ways Mandela and his movement intersected with Obama ’ s life , the two men were barely acquainted . They met face-to-face only briefly , in Washington , D.C. in 2005 when Obama was a freshman senator . A photo of that encounter sits near the president ’ s Oval Office desk .
The pair did not meet in 2006 when Obama visited South Africa , but the future president ’ s visit to Mandela ’ s cell at Robben Island produced one of the most evocative photos ever taken of him : an image of Obama staring through the bars that Mandela gazed through during his 18 years at the prison .
The two men spoke by phone on a few occasions , including after Obama won the presidency in 2008 . But Mandela ’ s health was failing , and by the time Obama first visited South Africa as president in June of this year , the man who brought down apartheid and led the country through a largely peaceful transition to majority-black rule was too sick to receive Obama .
During the 2006 trip , Obama told a South African audience that Mandela ’ s story and the broader struggle against white domination in that country played a pivotal role in opening his eyes to the possibility of a life in politics .
“ I was not born into a political family . I was not active in student government in high school , ” he said . “ But , when I was in college , there was one issue that moved me for the first time in my life to become politically active and play a leadership role in my community .
( TIMELINE : A look at major events in Nelson Mandela ’ s life )
“ I remember meeting with a group of [ African National Congress ] leaders , hearing the stories of their struggles of freedom and their leader Nelson Mandela , ” the future president added . “ It is likely I would not be here today speaking to you as a United States Senator had I not met with those ANC members one day in New York City . ”
